Unless you’re in a clean room (the kind in a laboratory or hospital operating room, not just a room that you cleaned), then yes, there are almost certainly fungus spores in the air around you right this second. Most of those spores will become nothing and/or be destroyed by the environment, but a few will happen to land on something that their species of fungus eats, at which point those spores will begin to grow. That’s why food you leave exposed to the air will start to mold: it becomes colonized by airborne spores.

This isn't against this channel personally, just saying that for me at least and a lot of people i know these science videos on youtube it would be so much easier to process and understand without all the jokes. It's just so much being thrown at you for a viewer, all this information you're trying to make sense of and you have to quickly realize what's important information and what's a joke. The jokes are distracting, and for me and i'm sure a lot of people, annoying-even if it was a good joke, because it distracts from the information and you have to try and think about the concept from the beginning all over again. For me i have to replay things multiple times a lot of the time to go back to try and connect the relevant concepts. I get why the jokes are there, cause creators think it would be boring without them, but a lot of people would prefer it that way- i wish there was at least one channel that had the helpful animatics and that was all it was. The 1.5 million spp estimate may now too conservative. That estimate (David Hawksworth 1991) was calculated from data before the start of the Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) era that allows for discoveries of greater fungal diversity per sample as well as the surge in fungal DNA sequences databases such as BLAST and UNITE. Accounting for fungi living in the tropics, aquatic, marine, and other habitats, the current range may be anywhere from 1.5 million to 10 million fungal species, with 5.1 million species being the most cited median value.  Fun fact: It's estimated that at most only 10% of all fungi can be grown artificially. The remaining 90% require sequencing for discovery and identification.

+Kevin Phannaraj  No, that's not what he said.  Decomposition can and does occur an many different ways.  This video is about fungi, not decomposition.  Also, when things decompose, they do not "turn in to bacteria". Just like fungi, bacteria can cause decomposition but they are not the result of decomposition. Bacteria reproduce just like any other life, either through sexual or asexual reproduction. The word "decompose" literally means to "become disassembled" or to "separate in to the constituent components of the original assembly".  There are many different biological, chemical, and mechanical ways for this to happen in nature. The processes used by fungi to decompose other materials or organisms are just a few of them.

The Pip Parasitism is a type of symbiosis. You're confusing it with mutualism. When it helps you, and you help it back, you are mutual AND symbiotic. Symbiosis literally means living together. A parasite feeds on you without you knowing about it. That is still symbiosis.

take a good look into the human microbiome, there are strong arguments to be made that people are less themselves than they are a collection of other organisms (especially when you look strictly at cell numbers; we have more symbiotic bacteria and fungi in and on us than we do our own cells). symbiosis is something that is WAAAAAY more prolific and complicated than most people can imagine and it quickly becomes a philosophical debate about where to draw the line between symbiosis and ecology. NOTE: i am using the broad and scientific definition of symbiosis here (although most of the things in and on our bodies are in fact mutualistic or at least mostly mutualistic) with 'sym-' meaning 'together'. the commenter above is using the more colloquial definition which actually is closer to mutualism (which is a type of symbiosis)

I do not consider either of your pronunciations of Fungi acceptable.   In (Classical) Latin, the letter "i" always sounds like the English name of the latter "e," no matter its position in a word. The way you pronounce it is how the diphthong "ae" should be pronounced, which would be the plural ending if it were feminine.   A soft "g" sound is never acceptable in Latin.

Pardon this geek-out. I've studied this subject and I love it. To add to the category of mutualists: endophytes. Fungal endophytes live in plant tissue walls where they can be beneficial or antagonistic. Sometimes one species of endophyte will be beneficial in one plant species but antagonistic in a different plant species. They produce secondary metabolites that can serve all kinds of strange purposes in a plant. They are also believed to be nearly universally present in plant species.

Square-cube law sucks. Basically, if we increase our size by a factor of ten in every direction, we would increase out strength (a function of the cross-sectional area of our muscles) by a factor of a hundred, but our mass by a factor of a thousand. This leads to a lot of problems. Added to that, gravity would be ten times stronger in your scenario (ten times the radius = 1000 times the mass), so we'd be comparatively a hundred times weaker than we are now, otherwise known as 'heart explodes'.

Also the sun would have to be much larger to match the earth proportionately, or lots of bad things would be happening. The point of the earth farthest from the sun would be insanely cold and the closest insanely hot.

The main limit to size of organisms in general is its food. The more you eat the larger you can grow. Squid grew over their entire life time, so most excess calories are used for growth. Mammals however stop growing after maturing. Chordates' sizes are determined mainly by genetics. Another limiting factor size is support. If a creature is to big for its body to support it will obviously die. So on your planet with 10x the gravity, it would be more likely that people would be 1/10th the size.

Hank, I don't think anaerobic respiration and fermentation are the same thing. Fermentation is producing energy from organic or inorganic compounds without a final electron acceptor, such as oxygen. If "g" turning soft when it's following "i" or "e" were native to English, we would be pronouncing get as jet and gift as jift. It's a rule common in Romance languages, like French and Italian but not in Germanic languages like German (duh) and English. The only reason it feels like it's part of English is that English has a lot of French words in it. It still happens in Scandinavian languages (which are a subfamily of Germanic languages) because they had the same sound shift. Funji is incorrect
